moves.1. e4 e6: I really don't like playing against the French; pushing the e-pawn to e5 seems dubious, but White often ends up playing it. But not here...
moves.2. d4 c5: Straightaway we are not going to see the usual French. I gather taking the pawn leads to some sort of Benoni game, which I didn't fancy. Nor did I like the idea of advancing the d-pawn.
moves.3. Nf3: I try to steer the game into a more familiar Sicilian.
moves.3... cxd4 4. Nxd4 Bc5 5. Nb3: 5.Be3 is better, developing a piece and defending the Knight. But this attacks Black's Bishop, so no real tempo has been lost.
moves.5... Bb6: Black uses a move to retreat the Bishop.
moves.6. Nc3: I'm already slightly ahead in development.
moves.6... Nc6: 6...Ne7 allows Black quicker castling, which is probably better.
moves.7. Bf4: Possibly not the best move, since Black can just drive the Bishop back by advancing the e-pawn and gaining space.
moves.8. Bg3: Going back along the c1-h6 diagonal makes the previous move a little pointless; this covers f2, something that grows to be most important!
moves.8... h5: Logical, I guess, to try to trap the Bishop.
moves.9. h4: Equally logical and necessary to prevent it.
moves.9... d6: Black is probably better getting out the other Knight, but my opponent likes attacking, risky and unusual strategies, and that Bishop could find a nice square on g4 supported by the h-pawn.
moves.10. Be2:
Interestingly, I'm already slipping into a defensive mind-set, protecting g4, when 10.
Qd2 followed by Q-side castling might give me a better edge.
moves.10... Nf6: Black gets out his other Knight.
moves.11... Be6: Black gets out his last minor piece and threatens to double my pawns.
moves.12. Qg5: Very suspect, in retrospect. This early sorte by the Queen results in Black gaining a momentum by driving it back and back and back...
moves.12... Bxb3: First, though, he carries out his plan to double my pawns, at the same time taking away the defender of the d4 square, something I hadn't really considered a problem.
moves.13. axb3 Nd4: But Black has thought of it and has a nice, if temporary, spot for his Knight.
moves.14. Bd3: My Queen is positively begging to be brought back, but I still feel there's a worthy attack. Somewhere.
moves.14... Ne6: d4 proves just a stepping stone in the start of Black's Queen-harrassing.
moves.15. Qf5: The Queen really isn't getting the message!
moves.15... Ng4: Building up a nice attack on f7, but with the Bishop guarding that square it's rather toothless - and Black has left d5 unguarded.
moves.16. Nd5: So I follow his early example and post a Knight there.
moves.16... g6: Black continues to hassle the Queen.
moves.17... Nd4 18. Qd1: Back, in fact, to the starting square, proving what a silly move Qg5 was.
moves.18... O-O 19. c3: Black finally castles behind a somewhat weakened defence. The computer actually has me ahead, but it didn't feel that way, as I drive away one Knight.
moves.19... Ne6 20. Be2: And get ready to do the same to the other.
moves.20... f5: Black doesn't want to retreat the Knight, and here I should have taken full advantage of the weakened Black defence with 21.exf5 gxf5 22.Bc4. I didn't because I thought Black might recapture the f-pawn with his Rook, building up his attack on f2. But that would have fallen foul of 22.Bxg4 followed by 23.Qxg4 and White is on top.
moves.21. Nxb6: Instead I give up my nicely posted Knight for the Bishop that's been bearing down onto f2.
moves.21... Qxb6: Now I have the Black Queen on the same diagonal. Not the smartest move.
moves.22. Qd5: I do get my own Queen to the centre of the board, though exchanging pawns on f5 first was still advisable.
moves.22... Rf6: Better to bring out the other Rook and defend from e8; I still have the option of exchanging on f5...
moves.23. Rd1: Instead I build up against the d-pawn, letting another chance to exchange on f5 go
moves.24. O-O: And here I blunder, not only passing up my chance for 24.exf5 gxf5 but castling into a mass of advancing pawns...
moves.24... Kg7: First, though, Black gives me one more chance by stepping aside with his King to unpin the Knight.
moves.25. Rd3: I want to double up my Rooks, but I don't get chance...
moves.25... f4: Having unpinned the Knight, Black doesn't attack the Rook with 25...Nc5, but drives back the Bishop instead.
moves.26. Bh2 Nc7: Black begins to chase my Queen again.
moves.27... Nxh2: Instead he rather loses momentum by exchanging off his nicely placed Knight.
moves.28. Kxh2 Qc6: Offering a Queen exchange that I don't fancy, even though it takes a bit of the pressure off and allows me to seize the open a-file with the Rook afterwards.
moves.29. Rf3: Instead I allow Black to exchange if he wants...
moves.29... Ne6: But he doesn't. I think we both wanted to keep potential attacks going and didn't want to go down to an endgame just yet.
moves.30. g3: Opening up the position, something I really do at my peril. But the game is being played at such a fast and furious rate I'm hoping there will be a few attacking chances.
moves.30... g5: Black makes the psotion very complicated indeed, and I really needed to spend some time analysing it before going ahead.
moves.31. gxf4 g4 32. fxe5: There are not many hiding places for the Kings now!
moves.32... Rxf3: Black can't afford to take with the pawn as my capture of his Rook results in a check!
moves.33. Qxe6: Now I'm banking on counterplay, with the Black King exposed.
moves.33... Re8 34. Qxd6: I doubt very much Black will fancy a Queen exchange to allow those two pawns to link up, though it's probably hsi best bet. Instead he tries something speculative...
moves.34... Rh3+ 35. Kg1: Only two squares for the King and clearly g2 is lethal after 35...Qxe4+
moves.35... Qxe4: It looks pretty dangerous without the check.
moves.36. Qf6+: But now I have the counterplay I want, and the game is very evenly balanced. Whoever blunders first might be the loser!
moves.36... Kh7 37. Qf7+ Kh6: And oh, how I want to take the Rook. But mate on h1 awaits me if I do. I guess the game could have ended in a draw by repetition here. But I'm starting to fancy my chances!
moves.38. Qf6+ Qg6: Maybe Black thinks I'm after the draw and tries this, which hands me a big advantage...
moves.39. Qf4+ Kg7: Now there's little to stop my Rook getting to d7 via d1.
moves.40. Qd4: Alas! I hand the initiative, and possibly the game, back to Black, by setting up this very obvious revealed check.
moves.40... Qe6: Whichj Black stops right away. It's not even that dangerous: 40...Qf5 41.e6+ Qf6 42.Bc4 Qxd4 Black still holds the advantage.
moves.41. f4: Ooooh but this is risky, even if I do get two passed pawns; that g-pawn is now looking hungry for Queening.
moves.41... g3: Forward it goes. And curiously, this ought to have been the losing move for Black: 42.f5 Qb6 43.f6+ Kf8 44.Rf5 Qxd4+ 45.cxd4 Rxh4 46.Bxh5 is surely enough. But I just see that unguarded pawn on h5...
moves.42. Bxh5: And think I have time to take it!
moves.42... Rh1+: As soon as Black played this I knew I was sunk. But as I've said, it was a game played at breakneck speed and understandable that Black missed a mate.
moves.43. Kg2: Obviously taking the Rook is suicide.
moves.44... Rxf1+: But Black also just sees the material.
moves.45. Ke4: My King is on the run, and it's surely only a matter of time?
moves.45... Qg2+: 45...Re1 brought mate closer, but I'm still sunk, I think.
moves.46. Kf5 Rf8+ 47. Kg5: I thought I'd escaped here, and I've certainly escaped the checks for a move or sao.
moves.47... Rf1xf4 48. Qd7+: Now it's my turn for a check or two, though Black still has, incredibly, a forced mate. But it's in 12 moves so I escaped.
moves.48... Kh8: I expected Black to interpose a Rook on f7, but his King scurries away instead.
moves.49. Bg6: Now I'm getting ready to deliver mate myself on h7. In my dreams... 49...Rxh4 50.Bf5 Qh1 51.Qd6 Rh5+ 52.Kf4 Rfxf5+ is the computer's continuation, ending in mate a few moves later. To my surprise, Black decides to liquidate the position...
moves.49... Rf4f5+ 50. Bxf5 Rxf5+ 51. Qxf5: I don't know whether Black missed something here, but now I am right back in the game, though with that pawn sitting on g3 it's probably drawn?
moves.51... Qf2: Yes, taking that Queen would be the answer to Black's prayers.
moves.52. Qc8+: I'm looking for drawing chances now; surely I can keep that King pinned down with perpetual checks?
moves.52... Kg7 53. Qxb7+: Actually, 53.h5 is more threatening; h6+ would be a difficult one for Black. But I'm focussed on keeping the Black King in check. And this square with my Queen covers g2.
moves.53... Kg8 54. e6: Oh dear; 54.Qd5+ keeps the Black King on its toes, but suddenly I think I have winning chances (nope) and foolishly hand the initiative back to Black.
moves.54... g2: Now that pawn really is dangerous, especially with my King on the g-file, something that might have been crucial.
moves.55. Qa8+: I must keep the checks going now.
moves.55... Kh7 56. Qe4+ Kh8 57. Qa8+ Kh7: I keep them going long enough for Black to offer the draw, which I gratefully accepted. Interesting to speculate about 58.Qb7+ Kg8 59.Qb8+ Qf8 60.Qxa7 g1=Q+ 61.Qxg1 Qg7+ 62.Kf5 Qxg1... but the game's pace meant that it went begging. A really wild one.
